Award.AwardTitle: Search for Tau Neutrinos in IceCube Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Embedded deep in the ice cap at the South Pole, the IceCube Neutrino Observatory (ICNO) is the world's largest and most sensitive high energy neutrino telescope. It is a 1 billion-ton detector using the Antarctic ice as a detection medium for high energy atmospheric and astrophysical neutrinos. Most of the neutrinos observed by IceCube exhibit energies in the range expected for atmospheric neutrinos originating from decays of particles produced in extensive air showers by cosmic rays coming from nearby sectors of the Milky Way Galaxy. These may be used to measure the fundamental properties of neutrinos. At higher energies, astrophysical neutrinos are key probes of the high-energy universe. Because of their unique properties, neutrinos escape even dense regions, are not deflected by galactic or extra-galactic magnetic fields and traverse the photon-filled universe unhindered. Thus, neutrinos provide direct information about the dynamics and interiors of the powerful cosmic objects that may be the origins of high energy cosmic rays: supernovae, black holes, pulsars, active galactic nuclei and other extreme extragalactic phenomena. This award provides funding for the University of Alabama (UA) group to search for a particular type ("flavor") of neutrino, the tau neutrino, in the IceCube data. Tau neutrinos have a negligible background from the atmosphere and would be a certain sign of astrophysical origin as well as offering insight into neutrino physics and oscillation in distant sources.

The PI will continue and enhance high school outreach by hosting an IceCube Masterclass: a one day event which gives high school students the chance to work with real IceCube data. The PI will develop a new Masterclass activity based on the UA group's tau neutrino research. The PI participates in public outreach activities that highlight IceCube's unique location and science goals.

If the astrophysical neutrino flux arises from pion decay as a result of cosmic ray acceleration in shocks, and assuming standard neutrino oscillation parameters, the detected neutrinos at Earth should consist of equal fractions of electron, muon and tau neutrinos. However, tau neutrinos have yet to be unambiguously identified in the astrophysical neutrino flux. The group will build on a proven track record in the tau neutrino channel and extend the search to lower energies and to previously unexplored signatures. With three more years of IceCube data, lower energy thresholds and increased signal sensitivity, tau neutrinos could be detectable by the end of the funding period.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IceCube Neutrino Observatory, in operation since 2011, is the largest neutrino detector in the world. Neutrinos are the lightest known particles and do not interact readily with matter; this makes them difficult to detect, but also means that they have the potential to carry information from deep inside extreme astrophysical events such as the explosions of massive stars, the merging of ultra-dense neutron stars and the activity of supermassive black holes in the centers of galaxies. In 2013, IceCube reported the detection of high energy neutrinos from outside our solar system; the source of these neutrinos is as yet unknown.

One property of the observed high energy neutrino flux which is still under investigation is the proportion of each type (or "flavor") of neutrino observed. According to the current state of knowledge of the properties of neutrinos, we expect to observe equal numbers of the three flavors of neutrinos: electron, muon and tau. Muon neutrinos are easily distinguished by the long trails of light (called "tracks") which they leave in the detector, but both electron and tau neutrinos can produce spherical light patterns (called "cascades") which can be difficult to distinguish except at high energies, where taus will produce a double cascade signature. Unlike the other two flavors of neutrinos, taus are not produced in appreciable numbers by cosmic rays interacting with the Earth's atmosphere, so the observation of taus would both confirm the astrophysical origin of the high energy neutrinos observed by IceCube and also reveal the physics of neutrino interactions in astrophysical environments.

This project has continued to refine the search for the tau double cascade signature by looking at the signal on individual IceCube modules. This so called "double pulse" search formed the basis of the dissertation work of a graduate student supported by a previous award to the PI. In this project, a new graduate student has worked on an algorithm to remove the effects of light propagation in the ice in order to better resolve the double pulse signal.

In the area of public outreach, the PI has organized an IceCube masterclass at the University of Alabama in order to educate local high school students about the field of particle astrophysics. The PI has also given several talks at public high schools, and was a plenary speaker and LOC co-chair at the Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics at the University of Alabama in January 2019.
